position.question: Will the Seattle Seahawks win Super Bowl LX?

decision.reasoning:
With no roster-specific or season-form information, I have to lean on broad priors about the franchises in the post-2019 era. My general prior (through mid-2025 knowledge) is:
- Patriots have been in a prolonged transition after the Brady era, with less evidence of sustained elite offense. They‚Äôve remained well-coached historically, but their recent ‚Äútrue contender‚Äù baseline has been shakier.
- Seahawks, even amid QB/roster transitions, have tended to field competitive teams with explosive skill talent and a higher-variance, ‚Äúcan get hot‚Äù profile‚Äîexactly the kind of profile that can win a one-game Super Bowl.
- In a single game on a neutral field, absent strong information, I slightly prefer the team with more perceived offensive upside / big-play capability rather than the ‚Äúsystem‚Äù team‚Äîbecause the tails matter.

The market is basically a coin flip (48.9% Seahawks). My prior is that Seattle should be modestly favored (low-to-mid 50s) given the Patriots‚Äô post-dynasty baseline uncertainty. So at ~49%, YES looks a bit underpriced.

<reasoning>

- Patriots have been in a prolonged transition after the Brady era, with less evidence of sustained elite offense. They‚Äôve remained well-coached historically, but their recent ‚Äútrue contender‚Äù baseline has been shakier.
- Seahawks, even amid QB/roster transitions, have tended to field competitive teams with explosive skill talent and a higher-variance, ‚Äúcan get hot‚Äù profile‚Äîexactly the kind of profile that can win a one-game Super Bowl.
- In a single game on a neutral field, absent strong information, I slightly prefer the team with more perceived offensive upside / big-play capability rather than the ‚Äúsystem‚Äù team‚Äîbecause the tails matter.

The market is basically a coin flip (48.9% Seahawks). My prior is that Seattle should be modestly favored (low-to-mid 50s) given the Patriots‚Äô post-dynasty baseline uncertainty. So at ~49%, YES looks a bit underpriced.

results.title: Super Bowl LX injury report: Updates on Drake Maye's right shoulder, Sam Darnold's oblique, more - CBS Sports
results.snippet: Seahawks: Seattle had perfect attendance at practice, but did have several players limited: Quarterback Sam Darnold (oblique), offensive tackle Charles Cross (foot), safety Nick Emmanwori (ankle), offensive tackle Josh Jones (ankle, knee), linebacker Demarcus Lawrence (rest), fullback Robbie Ouzts (neck), receiver Jaxon Smith-Njigba (rest), and defensive end Leonard Williams (rest). Patriots: Linebacker Robert Spillane (ankle) did not practice on Wednesday due to an ankle injury. However, he did tell the Boston Herald earlier in the day that he's "100% confident" that he'll be able to play in Super Bowl LX. Meanwhile, linebacker Harold Landry (knee) and offensive tackle Thayer Munford Jr. were both limited with knee injuries. Maybe the most important development on the injury front for New England comes at quarterback as the team listed Drake Maye (right shoulder) as a full participant.

Weather appears neutral.
